tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: This is a numerical calculation problem involving work rate. It requires multiple steps to calculate the individual work rates and then combine them to find the time taken by the team. The multi-step reasoning and the need to combine different work rates make it a medium-hard problem.

answer_validation.reasoning:
Treat each worker type as having a constant work rate. First compute the total work in 'wall-units' from any one group, then deduce individual worker rates, then sum the rates for the mixed team and invert to get time.

1) Let total work = 1 wall.

Skilled: 5 skilled workers build 1 wall in 20 days.
Total skilled rate = 1 wall / 20 days = 1/20 wall/day.
So rate of 1 skilled worker, r_s = (1/20)/5 = 1/100 wall/day.

Semi-skilled: 8 semi-skilled workers build 1 wall in 25 days.
Total semi-skilled rate = 1/25 wall/day.
So rate of 1 semi-skilled worker, r_m = (1/25)/8 = 1/200 wall/day.

Unskilled: 10 unskilled workers build 1 wall in 30 days.
Total unskilled rate = 1/30 wall/day.
So rate of 1 unskilled worker, r_u = (1/30)/10 = 1/300 wall/day.

2) Team composition: 2 skilled, 6 semi-skilled, 5 unskilled.
Total team rate R = 2 r_s + 6 r_m + 5 r_u
= 2(1/100) + 6(1/200) + 5(1/300)
= 2/100 + 6/200 + 5/300
= 1/50 + 3/100 + 1/60.

Find common denominator 300:
1/50 = 6/300,
3/100 = 9/300,
1/60 = 5/300.
So R = (6 + 9 + 5)/300 = 20/300 = 1/15 wall/day.

3) Time to complete 1 wall = 1 / R = 1 / (1/15) = 15 days.

Thus option D (15 days) matches the official key.

step_by_step: Step 1: Assume the total work (building the wall) is 1 unit of work (1 wall).
Step 2: Compute the rate of one skilled worker: 5 skilled finish 1 wall in 20 days, so group rate is 1/20 wall/day and one skilled worker rate is (1/20)/5 = 1/100 wall/day.
Step 3: Compute the rate of one semi-skilled worker: 8 semi-skilled finish 1 wall in 25 days, so one semi-skilled rate is (1/25)/8 = 1/200 wall/day.
Step 4: Compute the rate of one unskilled worker: 10 unskilled finish 1 wall in 30 days, so one unskilled rate is (1/30)/10 = 1/300 wall/day.
Step 5: Add rates for the mixed team: R = 2(1/100) + 6(1/200) + 5(1/300) = 1/15 wall/day.
Step 6: Time to complete 1 wall is the reciprocal of the rate: t = 1 / R = 15 days.

topic.name: General quantitative aptitude / work-rate problems
topic.syllabus_ref: GATE General Aptitude -> Quantitative Aptitude -> Time, Work and Data Interpretation

concepts.name: Inverse proportionality between time and rate

essential: Concept of rate as work per unit time
Understanding of inverse relationships (higher rate means less time)
Ability to sum multiple rates for parallel work
Translating word problems into mathematical expressions
helpful: Comfort with least common multiples for adding fractions
Experience with classical time-and-work aptitude problems

Main Concept: requires: Concept of rate (quantity per unit time)
enables: More complex resource allocation and scheduling analysis

difficulty_factors: Requires careful extraction of individual worker rates from group data
Involves adding several fractions with different denominators
Students may confuse total time with weighted average instead of using rates

textbook_references.author: R.S. Aggarwal
textbook_references.section: Basic problems on work and wages

textbook_references.book: How to Prepare for Quantitative Aptitude for the CAT
textbook_references.author: Arun Sharma

video_references.topic_covered: Introduction to time and work, unit work method, adding rates

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Define unit work -> Compute individual rates from group data -> Sum rates for mixed team -> Invert to get total time
key_insights: Treat the entire wall as 1 unit of work to simplify rate calculations.
Always convert group performance into per-worker rates before recombining in a new team.
Time is the reciprocal of total rate when total work is 1 unit.

formulas_principles.name: Work-rate-time relationship
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies when rate R is constant over time t and W is total work done
formulas_principles.relevance: Core relationship to move between work, rate, and time.

formulas_principles.name: Rate definition
formulas_principles.conditions: Used to compute worker rate from known work and time
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to find individual worker rates from group performance.

formulas_principles.name: Sum of parallel rates
formulas_principles.conditions: When multiple workers work simultaneously and independently on the same task
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to combine rates of skilled, semi-skilled, and unskilled workers.

formulas_principles.name: Time from total rate
formulas_principles.conditions: Total work W known, total rate constant
formulas_principles.relevance: Final step to compute total time to finish the wall.

industry_examples: Construction project planning: Estimating completion time when teams have workers of different skill levels and productivities.
Manufacturing assembly lines: Combining machines or workers with different throughputs to estimate total output rate.
Maintenance scheduling in airlines: Combining teams of technicians with different certifications to estimate turnaround time.
specific_systems: Aircraft maintenance crew scheduling for A-checks and C-checks where senior and junior technicians work together.
Composite layup teams in aircraft manufacturing where experienced and trainee workers collaborate.
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Accurate estimation of project duration with mixed-skill teams is crucial for cost control, resource allocation, and meeting deadlines in engineering projects, including aerospace manufacturing and maintenance.

common_mistakes.mistake: Taking a simple average of the given times (20, 25, 30 days) instead of working with rates.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Averages feel intuitive and quicker than setting up rate equations, especially under time pressure.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always convert to rates first: rate = work/time. Remember that when combining workers, you must add rates, not times.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to an answer around 25 days, which is far from the correct 15 days.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using group rates directly (5 skilled, 8 semi-skilled, 10 unskilled) without converting to per-worker rates, then incorrectly scaling.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They try to proportionally scale days instead of rates, mixing up direct and inverse proportionality.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Explicitly compute per-worker rate for each category before forming the new team. Write r_s, r_m, r_u clearly.
common_mistakes.consequence: Incorrect total rate and hence wrong time, sometimes close enough to tempt a wrong option.

common_mistakes.mistake: Arithmetic errors while adding fractions like 1/50 + 3/100 + 1/60.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: LCM and fraction addition under exam stress often cause slips.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Use a common denominator systematically (e.g., 300 here) and double-check numerators.
common_mistakes.consequence: Gives a slightly wrong rate, leading to a non-option time or a nearby wrong option.

common_mistakes.mistake: Forgetting to invert the total rate to get time when total work is 1 unit.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They stop after computing the total rate and misinterpret it as time.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Always finish with t = Work / Rate. If you assumed Work = 1, then t = 1 / Rate.
common_mistakes.consequence: Reporting rate (e.g., 1/15) as if it were time (15), giving a completely wrong magnitude.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Remembering that when multiple workers work together, you add their rates, not their times.
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use whenever you see a time-and-work problem with multiple workers or machines.

mnemonics_memory_aids.mnemonic: WRT triangle: Work on top, Rate and Time at bottom corners
mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Relationship W = R × T and its rearrangements.
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Helps quickly recall formulas: R = W/T and T = W/R.

flashcards.front: In time-and-work problems, when several workers work together, what quantity do you add: times or rates?
flashcards.back: You add their rates (work per unit time), not their times. Total rate = sum of individual rates.

flashcards.front: Write the three equivalent formulas relating Work (W), Rate (R), and Time (T).
flashcards.back: W = R × T; R = W / T; T = W / R.

flashcards.front: 5 workers finish a job in 10 days. What is the rate of one worker in jobs per day?
flashcards.back: Total rate = 1/10 job/day. One worker rate = (1/10)/5 = 1/50 job per day.

flashcards.front: If a team works at a rate of 1/15 job per day, how long to finish 1 job?
Why is averaging the times (20, 25, 30 days) wrong in the wall-building problem?
flashcards.back: Because workers work in parallel. You must work with rates (inverse of time) and add them, not average the times directly.

real_world_context.application: Construction project scheduling with mixed-skill labor
real_world_context.industry_example: A contractor has senior masons, junior masons, and helpers. Each group has different productivity. To bid correctly, they must estimate how long a specific team composition will take to complete a wall or floor.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Underestimating time leads to cost overruns and penalties; overestimating makes bids uncompetitive.

real_world_context.industry_example: An airline assigns licensed engineers, technicians, and apprentices to perform checks. Each category has different task completion rates. Planners must combine these rates to ensure aircraft are ready on schedule.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Incorrect estimates can cause flight delays, increased costs, and reduced fleet utilization.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Scan and recognize it as a standard time-and-work problem. If you are comfortable with rates and fractions, this is a quick 2-mark question; set total work = 1, compute per-worker rates, add, and invert.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If stuck, note that adding more workers should reduce time below the smallest given time (20 days). Eliminate options above 20; 15 is the only such option.
exam_strategy.time_management: Aim to finish within 2 minutes. If fraction arithmetic is slowing you down, approximate denominators mentally but still check which option is closest and reasonable (<20 days).

search_keywords: time and work problems mixed workers
inverse relationship between time and rate
GATE general aptitude time and work

alternative_methods.name: Direct proportion method using total work as LCM of denominators
alternative_methods.description: Instead of assuming total work = 1, choose a convenient total work equal to the LCM of denominators (e.g., 300 units). Compute how many units each group completes per day, then per worker, then for the team. Finally divide total work by team rate.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Avoids fractions by using integers; can be faster for some students. Cons: Numbers can become large if LCM is big; still requires careful arithmetic.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful if you are more comfortable with integer arithmetic than with fractions.

connections_to_other_subjects.Operations Research: Similar to machine scheduling and capacity planning, where multiple machines with different processing rates work in parallel.
connections_to_other_subjects.Project Management: Relates to resource allocation and critical path analysis, where team composition affects task durations.
connections_to_other_subjects.Industrial Engineering: Connected to work-study and time-motion studies that determine standard times and worker productivity.
connections_to_other_subjects.Basic Physics: Analogous to problems of combined flow rates (e.g., pipes filling a tank) where rates add when acting in parallel.

deeper_dive_topics: Stochastic modeling of worker productivity and uncertainty in project durations
Optimization of team composition to minimize project time or cost
Learning curves and how worker skill improvement over time affects effective work rates

syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: The question is a classic time-and-work problem, well aligned with the quantitative aptitude component of GATE and appropriate in difficulty for 2 marks.

rag_quality.notes: RAG context focused on aerospace topics (orbital mechanics, aerodynamics, structures, propulsion) and not on general aptitude or time-and-work problems. Solution relied entirely on internal knowledge of quantitative aptitude.

future_questions_potential: Vary the team composition and ask for the number of workers of one type needed to finish in a specified time.
Introduce workers leaving or joining the team after some days and ask for total time.
Include different daily wages for each worker type and ask for total cost along with time.
Ask for relative efficiencies (e.g., skilled vs semi-skilled) based on given completion times.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: 5 skilled workers can build a wall in 20 days; 8 semi-skilled workers can build a wall in 25 days; 10 unskilled workers can build a wall in 30 days. If a team has 2 skilled, 6 semi-skilled and 5 unskilled workers, how long will it take to build the wall?
